body: BP’s application to drill for oil deep in the pristine Great Australian Bight has been rejected for a second time by the offshore oil and gas regulator, Nopsema. The regulator said on its website on Monday evening the company would be given an opportunity to revise its plans and resubmit. The decision implies the regulator found BP’s plans did not meet its regulatory requirements, although the reasons were kept secret.   Related: BP oil spill in Great Australian Bight would be catastrophic, modelling shows    The company has already been given another chance to revise its plans and resubmit when Nopsema came to the same decision in November 2015. “Nopsema will typically provide two opportunities to modify and resubmit, but is not restricted to providing only two opportunities,” the regulator said in its announcement. The application process has been criticised in a recent Senate inquiry as secretive and weak, since most of the process is not made public, where it could be scrutinised.  The bight, off Australia’s southern coastline, is a haven for whales, sea lions and other marine life. It supports a large fishing industry and much of it is covered by nature reserves. It is unclear what sort of modelling BP has conducted of an oil leak in the bight, which is a major concern to conservationists since BP was responsible for the world’s biggest oil leak – the Deepwater Horizon spill of 2010 in the Gulf of Mexico – which occurred in calmer and more shallow waters than those in the bight. Just last week, Shell caused a large leak in the same waters. But modelling of a leak commissioned by the Wilderness Society suggested it would affect most of the southern coast of Australia, with the worst-affected areas depending on the season.   Impact analysis of oil spill trajectories in the Great Australian Bight    Related: Shell working to repair leak that spilled 2,000 barrels of oil into Gulf of Mexico    “BP should just give up and ditch its plans for the bight before it wastes any more of its shareholders’ money on an investment that the world can’t use and will become a stranded asset,” said the Wilderness Society national director, Lyndon Schneiders. The director of Wilderness Society South Australia, Peter Owen, said: “One would expect BP to go to great lengths to show the regulator it had learned from the Gulf of Mexico disaster and submit an application that would far exceed the required standards. Instead it again submitted a substandard application in the hope it will be approved.” The Greens senator for South Australia, Robert Simms, who established a senate inquiry into BP’s plans with independent Senator Nick Xenophon, also called on BP to give up on its plans. “It’s clear BP aren’t respecting the precious Great Australian Bight environment as once again Nopsema determine that BP’s shoddy environmental plan requires modifications,” he said. “We cannot risk a catastrophic oil spill in the Bight, a pristine environment which is home to endangered and threatened species like the southern wright whale and Australian sea lion. Any major spill would also decimate our coastal tourism and fishing industries which contribute 9,000 sustainable jobs and almost $1.5bn to the South Australian economy,” Simms said. Sea Shepherd Australia’s managing director, Jeff Hansen, said in a statement: “The whales of the Great Australian Bight can breathe a slight sigh of relief today. “Six years on, BP has still not cleaned up its catastrophic spill in the Gulf of Mexico, with mothers still giving birth to stillborn dolphin calves,” he said. “If BP is allowed to drill for oil in the Great Australian Bight, it’s not a question of if there will be an oil spill but when, and the Great Australian Bight is not worth the risk.” A spokeswoman for BP said although the decision meant BP’s application didn’t meet Nopsema’s regulatory requirements for approval, it wasn’t a rejection. “Nopsema has provided BP with a further ‘opportunity to modify and resubmit’ its environment plan, which is not a rejection but another step in the normal, iterative process with this regulator,” she said. “We have allowed sufficient time in our programme schedule for this regulatory process and continue to work toward commencing exploration drilling in late 2016, subject to the acceptance of our environment plan.”
webTitle: BP plan to drill for oil in Great Australian Bight rejected for second time
